Feature Detection at a given scale in scale-space

Consider scale-space representation of image :

where is the scale parameter, and is the two-dimensional variable-scale Gaussian kernel written as

The 2-jet at a given image point and a given scale contains the partial derivatives

From the five components in the 2-jet, four differential invariants can be constructed, which are invariant to local rotations; the gradient magnitude , the Laplacian , the determinant of the Hessian and the rescaled level curve curvature :

  • ,
  • ,
  • ,
  • .

These operators can detect different types of local structures:

  • A single-scale blob detector can be expressed from the minima and the maxima of the Laplacian response .
  • An affine covariant blob detector or a saddle detector can be expressed from the maxima and the minima of the determinant of the Hessian .
  • A straightforward and affine covariant corner detector can be expressed from the maxima and minima of the rescaled level curve curvature .

Some conclusions drawn by SURF:

  • Hessian-based detectors are more stable and repeatable than Harris-based counterparts.
  • Using the determinant of the Hessian matrix rather than its trace (the Laplacian) seems advantageous, as it fires less elongated, ill-localised structures.
